headline.main: When Illness Is a Blame Game

docs.abstract: Dr Ronald S Citron letter comments on Dr Jerome Groopman's April 21 article which suggests that medical patients may suffer unnecessary self-blame for their illnesses (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Your Cancer Isn't Your Fault'' (Op-Ed, April 21), by Dr. Jerome Groopman: Perhaps disease is not entirely our fault, but our parents'. The epidemiological literature shows that childhood habits, nutrition, lifestyle and other relevant exposures are seldom considered. There are no good studies looking at long-term nutrition and its effects. A glimpse of this issue can be seen from a study recently published showing that for the same amount of smoking, the risk of lung cancer increased markedly as the age of starting to smoke decreased.
